1.    The Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Stationary Source

At the Erie County Sewer District No. 2 (ECSD #2) Big Sister Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP), personnel are continually concerned with the safety of employees, the public, and the environment. The Accidental Release Prevention Program mandates operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the process at the Big Sister Creek WWTP.  To prevent possible releases of regulated substances, appropriate controls and techniques are used.  If such a release does occur, personnel at the Big Sister Creek WWTP, through the Division of Sewerage Management (DSM) are coordinated with the Erie County Department of Emergency Services and the Evans Center Volunteer Fire Department, whom all commit highly trained emergency response crews to help control and ease the effects of the release.


2.    The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled (primary activities, use of regulated substances, & quantities handled or stored)

?    The Big Sister Creek WWTP primary activity involves the treatment of wastewater.  Presently, there is one (1) regulated toxic substance above threshold quantity at the Big Sister Creek WWTP, which is Chlorine (Cl2).  According to the regulations, the Big Sister Creek WWTP is required to comply with the Program 3 Prevention Program.

?    Chlorine is used for the disinfection of wastewater, primarily to destroy and/or deactivate pathogenic organisms.

?    The maximum inventory of Chlorine at the Big Sister Creek WWTP is 8,000 lbs., which is broken down into four (4) one-ton (2,000 lb.) cylinders.  Three (3) cylinders are on the floor with only one (1) cylinder on the scale and in use at any given time.


3.    The Worst Case Release Scenario and the Alternative Release Scenario, including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario (include scenario & distance to endpoint).

The ALOHA (

Areal Locations of Hazardous Atmospheres) modeling program, version 5.2.3, was used to attain the required offsite consequence analysis for the Big Sister Creek WWTP.  The following provides a summary of the Worst Case and Alternative Release Scenarios:

The WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO submitted for Program 3 toxic substances involves a disastrous release from one of the chlorine cylinders.  In this particular scenario, 2,000 lbs. (the entire mass of the cylinder) of Chlorine is released in a gaseous form over a ten (10) minute span. Under worst case weather conditions being Class F atmospheric stability, 25?C (77?F), 50% humidity, no cloud cover, and 1.5 m/s (3.35 mph) windspeed, the maximum threat zone distance for a level of concentration (LOC) of 0.0087 mg/L is 2.7 miles.
 
The ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO for Chlorine involves a release from a single chlorine cylinder and is assumed to be a failure at the transfer hose, due to over pressurization or human error.  In this scenario, 800 lbs. of Chlorine is released in a gaseous form over a six (6) minute span.  The contents that remain in the tank after the pressurized gas is released will be of liquid chlorine. This liquid would be at a level lower than the release point and therefore, the contents would remain in the tank. Under neutral weather conditions (taken from Local Climatological Data 1999-2001 for Buffalo, NY) being Class C stability, 49?F (9.4?C), 45% humidity, 5/10 cloud cover, and 9.8 mph (4.38 m/s) windspeed, the maximum threat zone distance for a level of concentration (LOC) of 0.0087 mg/L is 1.7 miles.


4.    The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

At the ECSD #2 Big Sister Creek WWTP, personnel have taken all the steps needed to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements, found in 40 CFR Part 68.  The Big Sister Creek WWTP is subject to the OSHA PSM and EPCRA section 302 standards.  A brief description of the elements in the Release

Prevention Program are as follows:

Safety Information
The Big Sister Creek WWTP keeps a written record of safety information that includes information on the chemical hazards, operating procedures, and all equipment used within the process. 

Process Hazard Analysis
In May 1997, the Big Sister Creek WWTP conducted a thorough analysis to ensure that hazards associated with the process were identified and responded to efficiently.  The methodology used to determine and evaluate the hazards of the process was the What If/Checklist.  The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) is reviewed and updated (if necessary) and revalidated every five (5) years.  Any changes resulting from the PHA are completed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures
To safely conduct activities involved within the process, Big Sister Creek WWTP personnel maintain written operating procedures.  These procedures address each operating phase including initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup after an emergency shutdown.  Each year, the Chief WWTP Operator reviews the operating procedures and certifies in the annual report that all current operating practices are reflected.  In addition, all operating procedures are readily accessible to employees who work in or maintain the process.

Training
The Big Sister Creek WWTP has an extensive training program in place to ensure that employees involved with the process are completely knowledgeable about the operating procedures and hazards associated with them.  Mandated refresher training is provided at least every three (3) years and more often if necessary, to each employee involved in operating the process.  Currently, training is ongoing throughout the year in many areas.
 
Mechanical Integrity
At the Big Sister Creek WWTP, personnel carry out routine maintenance checks, inspections, and testing on all process equipment to ensure proper functioning.  Process equipment tha

t is accounted for, but is not limited to, includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps.  Any equipment deficiencies that are outside acceptable limits are corrected in a safe and timely manner to assure safe operation.

Management of Change
Written procedures are established at the Big Sister Creek WWTP to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures.  Any employee whose job tasks are affected by a change in the process is informed and trained.

Pre-startup Reviews 
Pre-startup safety reviews related to modifications in the established process are conducted as needed.  These reviews confirm that construction, equipment, safety, operations, and maintenance procedures are in place prior to startup.

Compliance Audits
The Big Sister Creek WWTP evaluates compliance at least every three (3) years.  Any corrective actions required as a result of the audit are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.

Incident Investigation
During the past five (5) years, there have not been any incidents at the Big Sister Creek WWTP.  If and when the occasion arises, any incident that has resulted in or could reasonably result in a disastrous release of a regulated substance would promptly be investigated. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  

Employee Participation
The Big Sister Creek WWTP has incorporated any appropriate employee comments into the Process Safety Management Plan (PSMP) (Appendix A).  In addition, all employees have access to the information developed under this standard. 

Contractors
On occasion, the Big Sister Creek WWTP hires outside contractors to perform maintenance and/or construction work.  Before choosing a contractor, the Big Sister Creek WWTP evaluates information regarding the contractors safety performance an

d programs. The contractors are informed of the known potential hazards related to the work. In addition, contractors will be explained any applicable provisions of the Emergency Response Plan (Appendix C).


5.    The Five-Year Accident History

The Big Sister Creek WWTP has an outstanding record of preventing accidental releases.  Due to effective release prevention, no accidental releases have occurred over the last five (5) years.


6.    The Emergency Response Program

The Big Sister Creek WWTP has a written Emergency Response Plan (Appendix C) that deals with accidental releases. The procedure includes aspects of emergency response including monitoring and detection, notifications following a release, direction and control, containment, evacuations, mutual aid assistance, emergency equipment inventory, first aid, review, updates and training, and other emergencies.  The emergency response equipment is inspected, tested, and maintained in accordance with the DSM Respirator Program.  The Emergency Response Plan is reviewed annually and promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within the process.

The Facility Emergency Coordinators (FEC) for the Big Sister Creek WWTP are:
?    Sewer District Manager - Marco Faraci
?    Chief WWTP Operator - Ron Schifano 
?    Senior WWTP Operator - James Supon 
?    Supervising Maintenance Mechanic - John Arrigo
?    Chief WWTP Supervisor - Glenn H. Absolom Jr.
The Emergency Response Plan (Appendix C) has been coordinated and verified with each FEC.  This procedure is also coordinated with the Erie County Department of Emergency Services and the Evans Center Volunteer Fire Department Inc.


7.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Big Sister Creek WWTP has all safety aspects covered, and have no planned changes at this time.
